clinical_study.brief_title: A Meditation Intervention on Subconcussive Head Impacts
clinical_study.official_title: A Meditation Intervention on Subconcussive Head Impacts

collaborator.agency: Mind and Life Institute, Hadley, Massachusetts

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research is to explore potential methods of rehabilitating changes observed from repetitive head impacts. Participation in this study will involve functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) imaging, anaerobic testing, a meditation rehabilitation intervention, and filling out survey information concerning subjective well-being.

detailed_description.textblock:
At first study visit, participants will be undergo fMRI arterial spin labeling scanning as well as a Wingate anaerobic exercise test on a stationary bike. Over the next two months, participants will participate in a breath work meditation or independent quiet study.
Participants will be randomized into one of two study groups. The intervention group will receive guided meditation. The control group will do independent school work quietly. Both groups will receive fMRI scans and perform an anaerobic bike test.
Participants will undergo a 30 minute MRI scan. After a preclinical screening, participants will participate in the Wingate anaerobic bike test. Participants will warm up for 5 minutes to become accustomed to the bike, completing 4-5 practice sprints. After a 1 minute rest, participants will perform a maximal effort test for 30 seconds. Upon completing, there will be a cool down and stretch period. During the warm up and test, participants will be wearing apical ECG leads to record heart rate activity. Over the following 2 months, they will participate in a meditation intervention therapy or independent study twice a week for 30 minutes each session.
During meditation intervention therapy, participants will lie on the floor with their backs and torsos elevated by a mat/soft blocks, with a foam roll underneath their knees. Participants will undergo guided breath work that will include a full body scan to bring participants to a present state. Upon completing all of the intervention sessions, participants will attend a follow up session of fMRI scanning and perform the Wingate test once again. In both the baseline and follow up tests, participants will fill out demographic surveys as well as subjective surveys concerning their well-being and perception of self.

Revised Child Anxiety & Depression Scale youth self-report questionnaire. The participants answer "never", "sometimes", "often", or "always" to a series of questions. The RCADS is scored either manually or by using an automated scoring procedure. Each item is assigned a numerical value from 0-3, where 0 = Never, 1 = Sometimes, 2 = Often, and 3 = Always. The highest score possible is 18, the lowest 0. This is an overall assessment of an individual's mental health and not what is considered better or worse. Examples include separation anxiety disorder or social phobia.

arm_group.description: The Intervention group will receive 30-minute sessions of guided meditation. During meditation, they will lie down with their backs and torsos elevated by a mat/soft blocks. They will undergo guided breath work.
The Control group will not have intervention. They will have quiet, independent study for 30-minute sessions.

intervention.description: Participants will meditate in response to the guidance provided by a trained meditation coach in person.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Participants recruited for this study will be comprised of adolescent athletes (age-range 13-18) engaged in American football who are enrolled in an ongoing NIH funded study of subconcussive head impact exposure (Whitlow: R01 NS091602), which acquires pre- and post-season MRI scans and cognitive testing.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Athletes will be excluded from the study if they suffer a concussion over the sports season or during the course of the proposed mediation intervention study. Athletes will be excluded if they experience claustrophobia entering an MRI scanner.
